Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: Laser Scribing of Multilayer Thin Films in Solar Cells: Defect Formation and Mitigation

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Grant Opportunities for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) grant provides funding for the investigation of defect formation mechanisms and the development of a defect mitigation approach for the glass-side laser scribing process of multilayer thin-film photovoltaic cells, aiming to better understand the influence of defects on solar cell properties and increase solar cell efficiency. Laser scribing from the glass (substrate) side, based on a micro-explosion mechanism, has led to increased scribe quality. Defects formed during scribing, however, are not entirely alleviated and keep solar panels from reaching higher efficiencies. The goal of this project is to significantly advance the state of knowledge in the glass-side laser scribing process of multilayer thin film solar cells using a fundamental approach. Via experimental and numerical investigations, defects will be systematically characterized, their formation mechanisms will be elucidated and issues in defect mitigation based on their influence on solar cell electrical properties will be better understood. The developed predictive capabilities will facilitate both exploration and optimization of scribing processes.

The success of this project is expected to lead to substantial enhancement in solar cell applications through reductions in defect formation resulting in reduced production costs and greater competitiveness of solar panels with alternate energy sources. The PI?s strong support from a key industrial partner could lead to rapid implementation of the developed knowledge in commercial solar cell panels with broad societal impact. The acquired fundamental understanding of the laser scribing process will be widely applicable to other absorber and contact layer materials in thin-film solar cells. Both experimental and numerical investigations will also benefit other applications such as the fabrication of LEDs and optical masks which utilize micro-explosion-based laser lift-off processes.

Institution.Name: Columbia University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: TRUSTEES OF COLUMBIA UNIVERSITY IN THE CITY OF NEW YORK, THE

ProgramReference.Text: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has significantly advanced the state of knowledge in glass-side laser scribing process of multilayer thin film solar cells.  The effect of spatial distribution of laser intensity on scribing quality has been investigated.  Non-uniform laser intensity is more readily available but may cause unwanted substrate damage, film residual, as well as poor scribe definition.  Uniform laser intensity is not directly available but yields more even material removal (Fig: Uniform Intensity Distribution) and better scribe definition.  The concern it may cause film delamination and crack formation has been investigated.  A coupled thermo-mechanical finite element model has been developed to analyze the spatial temperature and stress distributions within the film during the scribing process. The results found that a more uniform beam profile improves the uniformity and depths of the scribes, but increased thermal effects along the boundaries. A trade off strategy has been proposed. 

While glass-side laser scribing is meant to be a thermally-induced mechanical material removal method, thermal damage may still be significant if the process is not properly designed. It is obviously desirable to quantify the thermal damage, however, no approach has been developed to conveniently measure the size of the heat affected zone. Kelvin probe force microscopy was proposed and used to measure the heat affected zone via changes in the work function of the material (Fig: Work Function Measurement). It was found that mechanically dominated material removal yields the smallest HAZ while also achieving a satisfactory electrical isolation. 

It has established a comprehensive and physics based prediction capability of laser scribing induced defects, which impact overall quality and efficiency of solar cells.  A fully-coupled multilayer thermal and mechanical finite element model is developed to analyze the laser-induced spatial-temporal temperature and thermal stress responsible for SnO2:F and CdTe film removal (Fig: Numerical Modeling). A plasma expansion induced pressure model is also investigated to simulate the non-thermal film removal of CdTe due to the micro explosion process.  A CdTe removal process dominated by both brittle failure and delamination with reduced thermal effects, as captured by the numerical model, is desired for reducing scribing dead zones and interlaminar shorts. The knowledge of defect formation mechanisms during the micro-explosion dominant laser scribing of multilayer thin films is considerably advanced. Issues in defect mitigation based on their influence on solar cell electrical properties are better understood. The developed predictive capabilities facilitate both exploration and optimization of scribing processes and were verified experimentally including TEM (Fig: Defects Shown in TEM).

The outcome of this project is expected to spur significant interest in solar cell applications where defect formation is reduced and production costs are down.  As a result, the technology aids compete with alternative energy sources.  The direct involvement of a major industrial collaborator in the project is expected to facilitate commercialization at a fast pace. The acquired fundamental understanding of the laser scribing process of CdTe/SnO2:F will be readily extendable to other absorber and contact layer pairs in multilayer thin film solar cells. Experimental, material characterization, and numerical results will also benefit a range of applications which employ micro explosion based laser removal mechanism.

 


Last Modified: 02/19/2017
Modified by: Y. Lawrence Yao

    Brandal, G., Ardelean, J., O'Gara, S., Yao, Y. L., and Chen, H. (2015). Comparative study of laser scribing of SnO2:F thin films using Gaussian and Top-Hat Beams. 34th Int. Congress on Applications of Lasers and Electro-Optics. Atlanta, GA.

    Uniform Intensity Distribution
  • Extent of the heat affected zone over a range of incident laser pulse energies. The minimum at 22.5 ?J corresponds to thermally induced mechanical fracture becoming the dominant removal mechanism.
    Bucher, T., Brandal, G., Chen, H., Yao, Y.L. (2016). Shunt Loss and Thermally Induced Material Changes in Laser Scribing of Thin Film Solar Cells. 35th Int. Congress on Applications of Lasers and Electro-Optics. San Diego, CA.
    Copyrighted
    Y. Lawrence Yao
    Work Function Measurement
  • Complete film removal with a fluence of 1 J/cm2 at97.9 ns, the scribe radius is 28.7 lm, and delamination is 2.8 lmthrough the interface.
    Hongliang Wang? Y. Lawrence Yao? Hongqiang Chen (2015). Removal Mechanism and Defect Characterization for Glass-Side Laser Scribing of CdTe/CdS Multilayer in Solar Cells. Journal of Manufacturing Science and Engineering. 137 (6), 0610061.
    Y. Lawrence Yao
    Numerical Modeling
  • Cross-sectional TEM images of (a) scribe boundary and(b) magnified image at the delamination tip, showing dislocations formed at both between the two layers and grains which may introduce further crack initiation
    Hongliang Wang? Y. Lawrence Yao? Hongqiang Chen (2015). Removal Mechanism and Defect Characterization for Glass-Side Laser Scribing of CdTe/CdS Multilayer in Solar Cells. Journal of Manufacturing Science and Engineering. 137 (6), 0610061.
    Copyrighted
    Y. Lawrence Yao
    Defects Shown in TEM
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This project has significantly advanced the state of knowledge in glass-side laser scribing process of multilayer thin film solar cells. The effect of spatial distribution of laser intensity on scribing quality has been investigated. Non-uniform laser intensity is more readily available but may cause unwanted substrate damage, film residual, as well as poor scribe definition. Uniform laser intensity is not directly available but yields more even material removal (Fig: Uniform Intensity Distribution) and better scribe definition. The concern it may cause film delamination and crack formation has been investigated. A coupled thermo-mechanical finite element model has been developed to analyze the spatial temperature and stress distributions within the film during the scribing process. The results found that a more uniform beam profile improves the uniformity and depths of the scribes, but increased thermal effects along the boundaries. A trade off strategy has been proposed. While glass-side laser scribing is meant to be a thermally-induced mechanical material removal method, thermal damage may still be significant if the process is not properly designed. It is obviously desirable to quantify the thermal damage, however, no approach has been developed to conveniently measure the size of the heat affected zone. Kelvin probe force microscopy was proposed and used to measure the heat affected zone via changes in the work function of the material (Fig: Work Function Measurement). It was found that mechanically dominated material removal yields the smallest HAZ while also achieving a satisfactory electrical isolation. It has established a comprehensive and physics based prediction capability of laser scribing induced defects, which impact overall quality and efficiency of solar cells. A fully-coupled multilayer thermal and mechanical finite element model is developed to analyze the laser-induced spatial-temporal temperature and thermal stress responsible for SnO2:F and CdTe film removal (Fig: Numerical Modeling). A plasma expansion induced pressure model is also investigated to simulate the non-thermal film removal of CdTe due to the micro explosion process. A CdTe removal process dominated by both brittle failure and delamination with reduced thermal effects, as captured by the numerical model, is desired for reducing scribing dead zones and interlaminar shorts. The knowledge of defect formation mechanisms during the micro-explosion dominant laser scribing of multilayer thin films is considerably advanced. Issues in defect mitigation based on their influence on solar cell electrical properties are better understood. The developed predictive capabilities facilitate both exploration and optimization of scribing processes and were verified experimentally including TEM (Fig: Defects Shown in TEM). The outcome of this project is expected to spur significant interest in solar cell applications where defect formation is reduced and production costs are down. As a result, the technology aids compete with alternative energy sources. The direct involvement of a major industrial collaborator in the project is expected to facilitate commercialization at a fast pace. The acquired fundamental understanding of the laser scribing process of CdTe/SnO2:F will be readily extendable to other absorber and contact layer pairs in multilayer thin film solar cells. Experimental, material characterization, and numerical results will also benefit a range of applications which employ micro explosion based laser removal mechanism.
